brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of endoscopic full-thickness
      resection with laparoscopic assistance.

clinical_study.brief_title: Endoscopic Full Thickness Resection With Laparoscopic Assistance

detailed_description.textblock:
The laparoscopic resection with a linear stapler for subepithelial tumors (SET) can lead to
      excessive resection of healthy tissue of the gastric wall resulting in deformity or
      stenosis. Attaining a positive surgical margin is also possible. Endoscopic full-thickness
      resection (EFTR) can be used for tumor resection by direct visualization of the tumor from
      inside the stomach lumen leading to a free surgical margin with little resection of healthy
      tissue. In order to overcome current endoscopic technical limitations, we will combine the
      conventional laparoscopic approach with EFTR.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Gastric subepithelial tumor

          -  Invasion of muscularis propria on Endoscopic ultrasound

          -  Tumor size 1.5cm-5cm or increasing size during follow-up

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Bleeding tendency,

          -  Inappropriate condition for surgery with general anesthesia

          -  Refuse to be enrolled to study

clinical_study.official_title: Endoscopic Full Thickness Resection With Laparoscopic Assistance, Single Center Single Arm Study

oversight_info.authority: Republic of Korea: Ministry of food and durg safety

primary_outcome.description: successful En-bloc resection of subepithelial tumor and successful closure of resection site by Endoscopic full-thickness resection with laparoscopic assistance.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
